Regardless, one can't deny that the incremental progress of today form the foundation of tomorrow's miracles; I'm just tired of old jingles selling themselves as symphonies.

Sal, 'twas always thus. When something isn't understood, scientists propose hypotheses. Eventually, someone gets it right, and we have a paradigm shift. And mostly what we remember are the successful theories, not the also-rans. For example, the "luminiferous ether" that was proposed as a medium for electromagnetic waves is a famous example. Various attempts were made to explain the failure of the Michelson-Morley experiment to detect its effects. Finally, Einstein's Special Theory of Relativity made it irrelevant. Well, everyone knows about Special Relativity, because it's the one that worked.

I don't think we have any way of knowing at this point whether some among the theories being discussed are correct, or whether we'll see another paradigm shift. It could well be both. But remember that we're just verifying Einstein's prediction of gravity waves what, 80 years or so after he made it. It can be a while before the evidence is in.

Dear Dr. Carroll,

Nothing would make this non-scientist happier than seeing something new in the world of physics aside from the mild aftershocks that persist from the earthquakes of relativity and quantum mechanics over a century ago.

What appears to have become "natural" in the realm of physics are experiments only billions can buy, results so subtle none can see, language so grandiose few can believe, and scientific stasis that has turned the big bang into a punchline.

Come on, physics - get a half-life!

Cordially,
S.A. Traina

The "anthropic principle" is not mentioned directly in this article.
The word "tuning" (a proxy for the anthropic principle)
does appear. According to the anthropic principle a universe in which
it is possible to apprehend the universe is specifically tuned for
consciousness. If the recent evidence lends support to the existence
of multiple universes, then it also lends support to the notion that some
universes may be tuned for consciousness.
What can the theorists conjecture about the universes which are
not tuned for consciousness? They exist, but do they have topology
or structure of any recognizable kind?

Baron95 writes, "Wages mean nothing. What matters is created value." This describes our situation pretty succinctly. But how did we get to this point, where a vital service provider is less valued than an outsourced toy maker? As Americans, we don't have to accept the artificial system of economics that we've slipped into, we can do something about it, can't we? We have some control over our destiny, don't we? Child labor and slavery were once considered just how things were. How could our economy recover by changing those sources of value? Well, it did. And now we have a new problem. Inequity.
The moral to the story: Our economy is not an act of God, it is a fluid, complicated, and artificial system. We made it. We can alter it. We do not have to allow our own monster to devour us.

Henry Ford was an innovator.  I don't think employers have forgotten the principle of making it so that your employees can purchase your product - Walmart employees DO shop at Walmart!  It's simply that the standards of value have fallen and globalization of the workforce has a lot to do with that.  There is too much cheap labor.

Paul Krugman says so regularly: my spending is your income, and your spending is my income. When workers are starved of money to spend, our biggest economic engines chokes from lack of fuel.

A living wage is not beyond the means of most larger businesses. They are, for the most part, sitting on cash that they don't want to spend because they don't see good enough investment opportunities.

The reductions in turnover costs are a big key to this. Costco pays its front-line employees significantly more than Walmart. The former has long-term employees who have worked there for a decade or longer, need no government assistance for basic needs like food or rent or energy, and are in no rush to leave their jobs. Walmart has enormous turnover in its frontline--and the financial assistance these employees get averages around $100 a week, or a bit over $3 an hour as they tend to keep their people at just under 32 hours. They work hard to keep them part time employees, you see.

Employers have forgotten one of the maxims of Henry Ford: make it so whenever possible, your employees can also be an eager part of your customer base.

As one that follows this subject closely, this is a well written summary of the recent discovery for the lay reader.  That said, inflation itself is not really "natural" in that there is no real world example of inflation that we can point to in the present day universe.  Granted that inflation does explain many anomalies found in the very early universe, suggesting that there is something fundamental happening at that time.  My own view is that we still lack an understanding of how quantum mechanics and gravitation forces interact, and we will likely need to have such an understanding before a more complete theory of the early universe can be created.

I agree that Ma won those elections, and that his party must be unseated by democratic means. Having said that, here's the difference between those of us protesting outside of the Legislative & Executive Yuan--as opposed to being in California--and the Tea Party:
1. It is a fact that Ma was born in a foreign country. It is also a fact that he has claimed multiple birth places, none of them being Taiwan.
2. It is a fact that his entire family are citizens of foreign countries or holders or green cards.
3. Why emphasize #2? Because, just like those people who live in California, he has little to risk from engagement with China.
4. Why emphasize #1? He doesn't understand Taiwan.
5. Unlike the Tea Party, most of us support liberal views, politically and socially.
6. Unlike the Tea Party, most of us seek engagement with the rest of the world. We only oppose engagement with the country that threatens us and that blocks our access to the rest of the world.
7. There are pragmatic ways of dealing with China but Ma's, for those of us who can never leave here and who believe Taiwan to be a sovereign country, is not one of them.
Finally, one (not the only) reason why Ma was elected is that Taiwan, regrettably, permits people like his family to hold citizenship/permanent residency to foreign countries, while still enjoying all the benefits of our welfare system. These/(you?) people bleed Taiwan of resources, and vote without need to assume the consequences.

I think some context is worth considering when discussing this movement. On the economic front, starting salary in Taiwan has been stagnant if not actually regressed over the last seven years while living cost continues to rise. Then there is the political identity subtext. The protestors overwhelmingly belong to a young generation who strongly view themselves as, accordingly to reputable non-partisan polls, exclusive Taiwanese (versus "Chinese" or "Chinese+Taiwanese"). They are really assertive in their culture while also highly suspicious of China's territorial ambition.

And yet this administration, already deeply unpopular with overall approval rating as low as in the single digit, has continued to promote integration with China as if it is the only way out of the economic quagmire. Their only concrete talking point in selling the trade pact to young people is that that young people would have the opportunity to go to China and more than double their salary. Even if we discount the unrealistic nature of the promise (and besides, the fact that authoritarian regimes always alienate young people) , it is still not difficult to see why one would be upset with a government that effectively tells them to leave their homeland if they want anything better.

Rohit, relationships in India and the other countries you mention may be stronger (an arguable point, as this varies based on region, religious observance, etc.) but overall societal cohesion may correspondingly turn out to be lower. Such societal cohesion, or high trust in strangers (those outside one's friend and family circles) is very low in most parts in India, and the results are reflected in the poor quality of civic institutions and governance in India and those other countries. Maybe there is an inherent tradeoff between intimate relationships and wider societal cohesion; perhaps one rises only at the expense of the other.
